DOC.HEAD: OAS Urges U.S. Withdrawal; Bush Says Troop Return Is Unpredictable
EDs: Inserts grafs 14-19 w@ additional Bush, Warner quotes. Edits 1st Add to tighten.
DOC.TEXT:
The United States' intervention in Panama was rejected today by Latin American neighbors who called for an end to the bloodshed and a U.S. withdrawal. President Bush notified Congress that he could not predict the ``precise scope and duration'' of the military operation. The War Powers Act requires the president to formally notify Congress anytime he commits military force. In a written message, Bush accused deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega of directing ``vicious and brutal acts'' against Americans and asserted that the lives and welfare of U.S. citizens had been ``increasingly at risk.'' ``Although most organized opposition has ceased, it is not possible at this time to predict the precise scope and duration of the military operations or how long the temporary increases of U.S. forces in Panama will be required,'' Bush said. In Panama City, thousands of U.S. troops were settling in to restore order in the chaotic streets while in Washington, within blocks of the White House, the Organization of American States' political council voted 20-1 with six abstentions ``to deeply regret the military intervention.'' The United States cast the sole ``no'' vote. In a Spanish translation, the resolution used the words ``deplorar profundamente'' _ profoundly deplore. A resolution to ``condemn'' the invasion was never formally taken up. The Pentagon, revising its casualty report, said 20 American troops and two female dependents were killed in the first two days of battle, 202 were wounded and two were missing. American military aircraft were bringing the bodies of the dead back to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware, their coffins draped with American flags. U.S. officials said 122 Panamanian soldiers were killed and 45 wounded. Army Lt. Gen. Tom Kelly said U.S. troops had taken 1,500 prisoners, most of them regulars from the Panamanian Defense Force. ``This operation is not over, but it's pretty well wrapped up,'' Bush said Thursday at a news conference that coincided with return of the first bodies. This morning's report to Congress, ``Our additional forces will remain in Panama only so long as their presence is required.'' Sens. John Warner, R-Va., and Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., called on other Latin American states to recognize Panama's newly-installed U.S.-backed president, Guillermo Endara. The OAS group had not taken up the matter. Warner said it was time for ``the hand wringing and second guessing to stop.'' The senator in a television interview also said it would be helpful if Panama's neighbors would ``begin to rally behind him and perhaps even send in their own police ... so that President Bush can withdraw our troops as soon as possible.'' Endara acknowledged in an interview on ABC's ``Good Morning America'' that he could not safely walk the streets of his country today _ ``nobody is secure right now,'' he said _ but he claimed that he was the country's legitimate leader. ``I have the wholehearted support of the people right now,'' Endara declared. He said Noriega's capture was ``not absolutely necessary'' for an Endara government to establish roots. If Noriega is caught by Panamanian forces, Endara said, he could not under Panama's constitution be extradited to the United States, where he is under indictment on drug trafficking charges, ``so therefore I'm not looking for him.'' Following the OAS vote, U.S. representative John Masisto said, ``We're a little disappointed. It certainly wasn't an extreme resolution but it's a little detached from what is really happening in Panama.''
